newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian industry says rail budget to fuel inflation.
newsitem.headline: Indian industry says rail budget to fuel inflation.

text.p: A 12 percent rise in freight rates announced in India's annual railway budget on Wednesday is likely to increase production costs and fuel inflation, leading industry organisations said.

Presenting the railway budget for 1997/98 in parliament, Railways Minister Ram Vilas Paswan said he planned to raise freight rates for all commodities, barring essentials, by 12 percent. The increases would apply to all distances.
"The increase in freight rates will have a cascading effect," said A.S. Kasliwal, president of the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry (FICC).
"Going by past experience, there is a possibility of the increased freight rate pushing inflation by two to three percentage points which will undoubtedly affect business morale," Kasliwal said.
The Associated Chambers of Commerce and Industry of India (Assocham) said the "hefty hike" would increase production costs and fuel inflation.
Assocham President H.L Somany said in a statement that increased costs could have been met in other ways.

"The major part of the resources could have been internally generated by cutting down working expenses through increased operational efficiency and elimination of non-essential expenditure," Somany said.
Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) president Shekhar Datta said the freight hike was an unfortunate step, especially when industrial growth was showing signs of a slowdown.
He said instead of generating resources through increases in passenger fares and freight hikes, the railways must concentrate on increasing efficiency.
"It is alarming that from carrying 89 percent of the country's total freight traffic in 1950-51, the railways' share has dropped to 42 percent today," Datta said in a statement.
